answer_html: Since \(\displaystyle e^{-t}\) goes to 0 as \(\displaystyle t \rightarrow \infty\), the solution goes to 0 as well.
answer_latex:
Since $\displaystyle e^{-t}$ goes to 0 as
$\displaystyle t \rightarrow \infty$, the solution goes to 0 as well.
hints_html: Apply the limit \(t \rightarrow \infty\) to your solution from part (c).
hints_latex:

{(c)}.

question: 8 (d)
sols_html: Since \(\displaystyle e^{-t}\) goes to 0 as \(\displaystyle t \rightarrow \infty\), the solution goes to 0 as well.
sols_latex:
Since $\displaystyle e^{-t}$ goes to 0 as
$\displaystyle t \rightarrow \infty$, the solution goes to 0 as well.
sols_raw: Since <math>\displaystyle e^{-t}</math> goes to 0 as <math>\displaystyle t \rightarrow \infty</math>, the solution goes to 0 as well.
statement_html:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -2\\ 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)\end{aligned}\]

where \(\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}\) is the vector of unknown functions.

Describe the trend of the solution as \(t\to\infty\).
statement_raw:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

:<math>
\mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
2  &  -1
\end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)
</math>

where <math>\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}</math> is the vector of unknown functions.

Describe the trend of the solution as <math>t\to\infty</math>.
